headline: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signs bill banning "picketing and protesting" outside a private residence
author: Zoe Christen Jones
sentences:
The Battle Over Abortion
 More
 Florida governor signs bill banning protesting outside of homes
 Clarence Thomas says Supreme Court changed by leak of draft abortion opinion
 Thousands gather for pro-abortion rights protests across U.S.
 Sen. Thune says Democrats are using issue of abortion "to distract"
 Murder charge vs. women who have abortions yanked from Louisiana bill

In:
Roe v. Wade
Protests
Abortion
Ron DeSantis

The Republican governor said the new law will prevent protests in Florida like those staged by abortion rights protesters in front of the homes of U.S. Supreme Court justices' homes near Washington, D.C.
Attorney General Merrick Garland directed the U.S.

Marshals Service to provide additional support after Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Brett Kavanaugh, Samuel Alito and Amy Coney Barrett have all had continued demonstrations staked outside of their homes.
"Sending unruly mobs to private residences, like we have seen with the angry crowds in front of the homes of Supreme Court justices, is inappropriate, "DeSantis said in a statement Monday.
Nationwide protests have continued following the leak of a Supreme Court majority draft that suggest the landmark abortion ruling Roe v. Wade will be overturned.

Bloomberg
The legislation comes as Republican and Democratic lawmakers continue to debate the legality of protesting directly outside the homes of judges.
The news comes following a wave of protests over abortion rights, many of which have taken place outside lawmakers' communities and homes.
Demonstrators march near the home of Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts in Chevy Chase, Maryland, US, on Wednesday, May 11, 2022.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed a bill Monday that prohibits "picketing and protesting" outside someone's private residence.
The law makes it a second-degree misdemeanor to protest in a way that intentionally harasses or disturbs someone in their home.
"This bill will provide protection to those living in residential communities and I am glad to sign it into law."
Violators face 60 days in jail and fines of up to $500.
The Florida law is scheduled to take effect Oct. 1.
